column8: Divide around comma with a period; capitalize 'more'. > ... in the literature. More specifically...
perhaps this would be more intuitive if the examples in 2(a-d) were preceded by an ellipsis '...', to indicate connection to the preceding phrase 'Pensa un po'.
additionally, consider adding this quotation mark after the ellipsis, as in: 'Just think of it...'
although it's a bit unclear, worth making sure that semicolons aren't preferred in in-text parethesized references of this sort.

although this is an excellent abbreviation, it might be unintuitive to some readers, having not been clearly defined in a previous portion of the text (the closest approximation is 'featural characterization of Relativized Minimality' in the paragraph above).
I couldn't parse this sentence. Is it supposed to start with 'Here' (or just 'we')?

additionally, worth asking whether the comma should also appear in 1(a-b) after the marked-prosody phrases 'A MARIA' and 'IL TUO LIBRO', although i understand the pause might not be intended here.  there seem to be some potential, minor inconsistencies of punctuation in the glosses. worth a second glance.
according to the title of Durrleman's (2008) paper in the references, this should be 'Jamaican Creole'.

according to the guidelines, all examples should be referenced and include info about source/language.  since this italian data is frequently found in the squib without these additions, i will not continue to comment on this issue, but please reference the guidelines § 3.2.6 'glossed examples' for the stipulated format.
is not stipulated anywhere in the guidelines, though it seems to be what others would generally stick in a footnote on the first page. Does LSP accept this sort of acknowledgement format?

technically, the guidelines stipulate that all examples should be accompanied by references (and language and source info).  since all of the examples in this paper abound in the format highlighted here, i will abstain from repeating this comment.
